Questions.qstn: A garden store purchased a number of shovels and a number of rakes.  If the cost of each shovel was $14 and the cost of each rake was $9, what was the total cost of the shovels and rakes purchased by the store?
Questions.qstnStmt1: (1) The ratio of the number of shovels to the number of rakes purchased by the store was 2 to 3.
Questions.qstnStmt2: (2) The total number of shovels and rakes purchased by the store was 50.
Questions.opt1: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient to answer the question asked.
Questions.opt2: Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient to answer the question asked.
Questions.opt3: BOTH statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are sufficient to answer the question asked, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
Questions.opt4: EACH statement ALONE is sufficient to answer the question asked.
Questions.opt5: Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient to answer the question asked, and additional data are needed.

Questions.qstn: Of the students who eat in a certain cafeteria, each student either likes or dislikes lima beans and each student either likes or dislikes brussels sprouts.  Of these students, 3 2 dislike lima beans; and of those who dislike lima beans, 5 3 also dislike brussels sprouts.  How many of the students like brussels sprouts but dislike lima beans?
Questions.qstnStmt2: (2) 40 of the students like lima beans.
Questions.opt1: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient to answer the question asked.
Questions.opt2: Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient to answer the question asked.
Questions.opt3: BOTH statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are sufficient to answer the question asked, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
Questions.opt4: EACH statement ALONE is sufficient to answer the question asked.
Questions.opt5: Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient to answer the question asked, and additional data are needed.

Questions.qstn: How many different prime numbers are factors of the positive integer n ?
Questions.qstnStmt1: (1)  Four different prime numbers are factors of 2n.
Questions.qstnStmt2: (2)  Four different prime numbers are factors of n2.

Questions.qstn: Of the 800 students at a certain college, 250 students live on campus and are more than 20 years old.  How many of the 800 students live on campus and are 20 years old or less?
Questions.qstnStmt1: (1)  640 students at the college are more than 20 years old.
Questions.qstnStmt2: (2)  60 students at the college are 20 years old or less and live off campus.
